data.title: Doctor Who to be even scarier with ‘3D immersive sound’ episode
data.meta_description: When Doctor Who first materialised on screens, the eerie sound effects created by the BBC’s pioneering Radiophonic Workshop terrified viewers. […]
data.text:
When Doctor Who first materialised on screens, the eerie sound effects created by the BBC’s pioneering Radiophonic Workshop terrified viewers.

Now the first Doctor Who episode broadcast in “immersive 3D sound” promises to have viewers hiding behind the sofa once again.

Knock Knock, a creepy, haunted-house set story to be shown this Saturday, will be made available in a special edition, using pioneering sound technology being developed by the BBC.

“Binaural Doctor Who should have people hiding behind the sofa again.” BBC audio scientist Chris Pike

The “binaural” audio track gives the impression of specific sounds being in front or behind the viewer.

Viewers wearing headphones, who play the episode on the iPlayer, will enjoy a 3D surround sound experience, designed to enhance the story’s scare factor.

Chris Pike, senior scientist at the BBC’s R&D audiolab, said: “The story is set in a creepy house with creaking floorboards any mysterious winds.”

“We’ve been able to make it even scarier by adding the binaural effects to the soundtrack. It should have people hiding behind the sofa again.”

The Binaural sound production technique mimics the natural hearing cues created by our head and ears to create the impression of 3D sound.

Mr Pike added: “The technology allows us to create a richer 3D environment for the listener compared to listening to stereo programmes over headphones which gives a flat impression with sounds coming from inside the head.”

Binaural BBC Proms

The Binaural sensation of placing a listener “inside the room” with performers and musicians has been tested at the BBC Proms.

A concert last year was relayed using eight “hypercardioid” directional microphones to pick-up sound from the front, behind, above and below at the Royal Albert Hall.

More BBC radio dramas will be broadcast in a binaural format for headphone-wearing listeners tuning in on smartphones.

Radiophonic pioneers

Back in 1963, the eerie Doctor Who theme was created by the Radiophonic Workshop’s Delia Derbyshire using a plucked string, tape manipulation and oscillators.

The whooshing Tardis was produced by slowing down the sound of keys being scraped across a rusty piano string.

VR experiences

Binaural is a vital component of the Virtual Reality experiences that the BBC R&D team are developing. The Turning Forest, the BBC’s first VR interactive film, was recorded on location in a forest using 20 microphones to create an immersive, sound experience which changes depending on the headset-wearing viewer’s orientation.

Mr Pike said: “Binaural also has good applications for natural history shows like Planet Earth, where you hear the distinctive sound of an animal moving into shot.”

But for dramas like Doctor Who, binaural works best when the sweeping orchestral backing is turned down, leaving a more spartan, atmospheric soundtrack.
